title: How to Build a Balance Board

steps.title: Figure out what size board you want.
steps.content: Figure out what size board you want. This will depend mostly on how tall you are. The board should be long enough so that you can have a wide, shoulder-width stance while riding it. It should also be wide enough so that your feet won't hang off the sides. Around 33" by 14" is good. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Purchase a piece of 3/4" plywood big enough to cut down to the size you want the board to be with some extra.
steps.content: Purchase a piece of 3/4" plywood big enough to cut down to the size you want the board to be with some extra. Also purchase some large diameter, (5" to 7" is good), thick walled PVC or ABS pipe. It should be long enough to fit the width of your board, and strong enough that it does not flex easily, since you will be putting your weight on it. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the plywood to size, and the PVC, if needed.
steps.content: Cut the plywood to size, and the PVC, if needed.

steps.title: Using the excess plywood, cut 2 pieces, each about 2 inches (5.1 cm) wide and 14 inches (35.6 cm) (width of board) long.
steps.content: Using the excess plywood, cut 2 pieces, each about 2 inches (5.1 cm) wide and 14 inches (35.6 cm) (width of board) long. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Secure these two pieces at either end of the board, on the same side of the board, for stoppers.
steps.content: Secure these two pieces at either end of the board, on the same side of the board, for stoppers. Use these for safety if you think you will hurt yourself, otherwise you don't need them. These will help the board not slip off the end of the pipe while riding. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Lay the pipe on the floor and place the board on top of it.
steps.content: Lay the pipe on the floor and place the board on top of it. Put on a safety helmet, wrist guards, elbow and knee pads. Again, you only need these if you think you might get hurt. Step on the board carefully, (using a chair or someone's shoulder for support, at least the first few times), and test your balance! [5] X Research source
